title: Animal Farm - Context and Background

options.text: A government that is controlled by a single person

options.label: C
options.text: To explore the effects of totalitarianism on ordinary people

title: Who am I? A philosophical inquiry - Amy Adkins

multiple-choice.question: What are the three little words that have sent poets, philosophers, and seekers on a quest for answers throughout history?
According to the transcript, what is the title of the rock anthem that The Who sang about the subject of identity?
What is the name of the Greek historian who used the story of a ship to demonstrate the complexity of the persistence of identity?
According to the transcript, what is the name of the mythical founder King of Athens who slayed the Minotaur at Crete?
The Ship of Theseus paradox raises questions about the nature of identity and change. What is the main issue at the heart of this paradox?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether a ship can be rebuilt from its constituent parts

options.label: B
options.text: Whether a ship can be replaced with an identical one

options.label: C
options.text: Whether a ship can change its purpose or function

options.label: D
options.text: Whether a ship can exist without its original parts

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens when we consider the twist of the original ship being cast off and rebuilt into a new ship?

options.label: A
options.text: We create a new entity that is qualitatively identical to the original ship

options.label: B
options.text: We create a new entity that is numerically identical to the original ship

options.label: C
options.text: We create a new entity that is both qualitatively and numerically identical to the original ship

options.label: D
options.text: We create two entities, one that is the original ship and the other that is the rebuilt ship

multiple-choice.question: The Ship of Theseus paradox has implications for our understanding of identity and change. What is one way in which this paradox relates to our own lives?

options.label: A
options.text: We are all constantly changing, like the ship, but still remain the same

options.label: B
options.text: We are all fixed entities, like the ship, and never change

options.label: C
options.text: We are all made up of parts that can be replaced, like the ship

options.label: D
options.text: We are all qualitatively identical to each other, like the ship

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one possible answer to the question "Who am I?"

options.label: A
options.text: "I am a legendary hero sailing a powerful ship on an epic journey."

options.label: B
options.text: "I am a collection of constantly changing parts."

options.label: C
options.text: "I am a fixed entity with a clear purpose and function."

options.label: D
options.text: "I am a ship that can be rebuilt from its constituent parts."

multiple-choice.question: The Ship of Theseus paradox is an example of a philosophical paradox. What is the main characteristic of a philosophical paradox?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a logical contradiction that cannot be resolved

options.label: B
options.text: It is a puzzle that requires a logical solution

options.label: C
options.text: It is a thought experiment that challenges our understanding of the world

options.label: D
options.text: It is a debate that requires a moral or ethical solution

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the purpose of the story of the Ship of Theseus?

options.label: A
options.text: To demonstrate the complexity of the persistence of identity

options.label: B
options.text: To illustrate the importance of change and adaptation

options.label: C
options.text: To show the limitations of language and communication

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a clear and definitive answer to the question "Who am I?"

options.label: B
